Welcome to Detroit, mothafucka Boy I need no halves and halves, I want the game in entirety 100 percent cut, no stitches required Welcome to Detroit where if you get that promotion Don't worry, man them bullets will still be at your ass firin' I still call it safe, I would suck if I was umpirin' Boy I hit the beat I just treat that shit like a diary I'm offended if you hear my new shit and you ain't rewindin' me Self made, I never needed your bail or a wire, see I'm never callin' collect, I call to collect My homie wanted a Chevy so I put my dog in the vet Plus I'm so loyal that that paper, boy, is all that I fetch If the ball in my hand then the ball in the net Bitch I'm the D, can't no offense dunk on me I'm Mr. Big Shot, these hoes get drunk off me I'm overrespected, my mama gated community's overprotected So futuristic, I'm already over my next bitch Reminiscin' on listenin' to 50 fifty times a day Back when tenth grade was like fifty days away Tryna get paid fifty ways a day Used to put fifty on the layaway, now my closet fifty shades of grey Twenty six and I done lived a lifetime a few times From futons to Grey Poupons In church tryna get a little savings, yeah coupons I spit that A1 every day, I'm hittin' new primes Now the stakes high, niggas surprised at the new lines Or takin' down my number like "you still ain't got a new line?" Nah it's the same, we've been laborin' for years I know it took way longer than nine Months, but fuck it, it's all in due time I turned a blunt to a roach with dreams of bein' a Beatle though Don't want to, I need to, gotta learn to keep it cerebral When you come up in a place where Everyone got a piece but ain't peaceful This is just part one, wait 'til the sequel Tell 'em if they want it, they can come get that (static) I swear I love my city, I just want a little (static) See me, they salute me, they ain't ready for that (static) Detroit vs. Everybody Comin' from them streets where they thirsty, starvin' to eat Just a step away from felon, that's why they call it the D On your bleeder, ho, reason for all of this honesty Honestly no honor roll, but honored up in these streets Cause I'm a Linwood nigga, them young niggas say Put a stack on your head, you'll bleed a lake on Grand River And to think y'all hood harder then I might beg to differ Know some killers pull the trigger for a Swisher and Molly In a blink I'll hit your kisser, bet you ass ain't rememberin' They say my city's tougher than two fat bitches scissoring So nigga I'm a veteran, retire my letterman I had K's in front ya school, but I ain't go to Kettering Cough up a lung, 313 where I'm from Xan got me cross eyed like Bernstein's son And these niggas try to copy but I hold on this time It's us vs. them, Detroit vs Everybody Lately it seems as if it's me against the world Like it was before my life became a movie And they used to use my mothafuckin' trailer to tease me with But I flipped that script like AB filler Painkillers to pop that lid off that safety seal It made me feel amazing, made me celebrate me And if I may reiterate, I ain't even need a script I ain't bein' conceited But I made it to radio, eat a dick I still never ABC the shit Mainstream appeal and the skill is what made me iller Since before they called Jay Dee Dilla I was daydreamin' one day I would be the shit And if I ever end up escapin' the Streets I swear that I would stay here Still in it, I'm crazy, I'll always be real Don't make me steal an 18 wheeler Break all of my friends out of here and Take 'em straight to the Mercedes dealer Peel off back to the same block that we came from, on a rampage You crazy for me to flip What's makin' you think I need a switch? Cause I'm Adrian Peterson When he's raging and heated and on the way to go beat his kid On the track I spank like he just did (DETROIT!) I can't never leave this bitch Sick of bein' treated like me and shit But Jesus, I can just see why people quit callin' me to do features And them cyphers on BET cause if I wasn't me I probably wouldn't want to play with me neither, shit Seems to be reachin' this fever pitch 180 degrees in here trying to wait for the cedar chips MCs just bit off more than they can Chew like a face full of Swedish Fish Or Lorena with two penises Hateful ingeniousness, this inconvenience And for the record, You won't want this kind of static in Your life, when I'm makin' you cling to it They consider tryna reinsulate yah When it's maybe in for another crazy winter It's so cold in the D, it is as days begin to tick away But ain't this what really made me into the angry bitter blonde Sick of bein' underdog Don't make me unleash this shit, release this Pit May even seem as if I'm yankin' your chain a bit or maybe the way in which I'm sayin' shit Is playin' with your relation, changin' it It's still the same and Shady's still a lady killer Since the day I went insane and attacked the baby sitter With a potato peeler and mushed her face into the entertainment center It's like another plane just entered into Ukraine again The Bermuda Triangle and attempted to make a safe descent Awaiting anyone who ain't affiliated, it could be danger Did you make arrangements with the gangsters 'fore you came here? {I think that enunciation and delivery is a big part of being a great MC.  Voice control, cadence, it all plays into how powerful the lyrics can be if verbally expressed.  You can take the exact same speech of some of the great orators of all time and give the written version of it to someone else and the impact would be completely different? Why?  Itâ€™s the voice, the tempo, the delivery, etc.  Just spitting your lyrics, no matter how good it is, becomes damaged goods if the listener canâ€™t hear it without having to constantly hyper-focus or flip the narrative to where they have to make themselves believe that it is an acquired taste.  Hey, that might be partly true but the real truth is that you are not a good rapper.  You are a good writer.  Itâ€™s this feature that separates poets from rappers. I think that concept has become lost for some reason. Danny Brown might be a good writer but the way itâ€™s delivered makes it difficult to care about it}

{2019/10/30}
{Maaan if you've never been to Detroit you won't understand.. that city is unique and I've been to a lot of citys.. there's history everywhere you look.. beautiful rubble.. it tells a story.. I've never been anywhere in my life that sticks in my mind like Detroit.. and I've been to 3rd world country projects.. Detroit got weird energy.. unexplainable.. but if you've been you'll understand. I believe it's cursed land. I caught 3 felonies on that trip. I was in the projects.. hit 8 mile because i was an em fan.. understood his line to icp "you aint seen  a fuckin mile road south of 10" it clicked because when you head north the mile roads go up and the environment fades from gritty to safer. Like i said I'm not from Detroit but i felt and experienced it.. unfortunately i ended up in prison for five years from that trip.. probably the reason Detroit stick in my mind because i was on some wild shit back then. Also all of these drug references in a few Detroit artists makes sense to the landscape of Detroit. A beautiful yet depressing city full of energy good and bad}

{2:55 hats off}
{Listen to me. I can write a comeback for every rapper in that song except Eminem. Next in line would be Big Sean. I am impressed by that young man for real. I was skeptical when I heard him rapping on Ariana Grande stuff but I Respect his lyrical prowess now. Eminem is easily the Einstein of rap at this point in life in my humble opinion. The only 3 rappers I feel did well in a song with Eminem as far as lyrical content are Trick Trick, Royce da 5'9 and T.I. That is just what I have heard though. If there is someone better I seriously sincerely beg of you to educate and I WILL respond. I have written my own rhymes for over 15 years now many of which have been quoted by famous artists which lets me know I have been on the right track. With Eminem's evolution, I dare say that he has surpassed Pac unfortunately. His song "Good Guy" is completely flawless... even if people were dumb enough to consider him an "idiot savant." I declare that 3 decades would likely pass before his equal or better could arrive at a minimum to challenge him as a lyricist or songwriter; myself included, which isn't saying much. The closest brilliant light of lyrical content would be either Nas or Logic and Logic is still raw at this point from what I can comprehend.}

{Big Sean went absolutely nuts on this shit.  With a beat like this on a song called "Detroit" with Eminem in the studio next to you when you're born and raised in Detroit you KNOW you're playing your A+ game! {Eminem uses an internal rhyme pattern where the rhyming words and syllables don't have to be in rhythm with each other. Along with an incredible ability to twist words and enunciations to make things which don't technically rhyme sound like they do rhyme.  Basically they don't technically rhyme but it rhymes within the song to the human ear. I've heard/read him explaining this several interviews.  With the weird ass, empty and juvenile shit he's made he isn't the most consistent rapper. But his absolutely amazing talent and the greatness of his quality music is undeniable. When Eminem is focused and motivated he's one of the greatest song writers in history. When his not focused and motivated he's like Fred Durst with more talent and better marketing.  There's no other artist who's catalogue I have more of a love - hate relationship with than Eminem's. His good stuff absolutely untouchable. His bad stuff is absolute trash. But his legacy was safe and secure well over a decade ago.}

[Big Sean:] Shawn Don (Welcome to Detroit) Boy I need no half's a half, I want the game in entirety Hundred percent cut, no stitches required Welcome to Detroit where is you get that promotion Don't worry, man those bullets will still be at your ass firin' I still call it safe, I would suck if I was umpiring Boy hit the beat & just treat that shit like it's a diary I'm offended if you hear my new shit and you ain't rewindin' me Self made, I've never needed your bail or a wire, see I'm never callin' collect, I call to collect My homie wanted a Chevy so I put my dawg in a vet Ha plus I'm so loyal that that paper, boys, is all that I fetch If the the ball in my hand then the ball in the net Bitch I'm the D, can't no offense dunk on me I'm Mr. Big Shot, these hoes get drunk off me I'm over respected, my mama gated community's over protective So futuristic, I'm already over my next bitch Reminiscin' all listening to 50 fifty times a day Back when tenth grade was like 50 days away Tryin' to get paid 50 ways a day Used to put 50 on the layaway, now my closet 50 shades of grey Twenty six and I done lived a life time a few times From futons to Grey Poupon's In church tryin' to get a little savings, yeah coupon I spit that A1 every day, I'm hittin' new primes Now the stakes high, niggas surprised at the new lines Takin' down my number like "you still ain't got a new line?" Naw it's the same, we been laborin' for years I know it took way longer than nine months, but fuck it, it's all in due time I turned a blunt to a roach with dreams of bein' a Beatle though Don't want to, I need to, gotta learn to keep it cerebral When you come up in a place where everyone got a piece but ain't peaceful This is just part one, wait 'til the sequel [Dej Loaf:] Tell 'em if they want streets where they thirsty, starvin' to eat Just a step away from failin', that's why they call it the D Arguably the whole reason for all of this honesty Honestly no honor roll, but honored up in them streets Cause I'm a Linwood nigga, them young niggas hit ya Put a stack on your head, you'll bleed a lake on Grand River If you think your hood harder then I might beg to differ Know some killas pull the trigger for a Swisher and Miller If the blicka hit ya kisser, bet yo ass not remembering They say my city's tougher than two fat bitches scissorin' So nigga I'm a veteran, retire my letterman Had K's in front ya school, but I ain't going to Ketteran Cough up a lung, 313 where I'm from Ghan got me cross eyed like Bernstein's son Any nigga try to copy, put a hole in his top It's us vs. them, Detroit vs Everybody [Eminem:] Lately it seems as if it's me against the world Like it was before my life became a movie And they used to use my mother fuckin' trailer to tease me with But I flipped that script like a refilla a Painkillers to pop that lid off that safety seal It made me feel amazing, navy seal of bravery And if I may reiterate, I ain't even need a script Ain't bein' conceited But {BIG SEAN sounded like he put a lot of extra detail in that verse. Yeah, he had different flows & good punchlines, but the most interesting part was the amount of attention he gave towards every syllable that left his mouth. He had one flow.... his voice pitch changed from low to high every syllable. EMINEM... at this point, I have to stop trying to understanding what the fuck is wrong with his mind. He's so good at matching syllables that he might be in the middle of 4 different rhyme schemes with one bar. My brain hurts trying to identify what kind of patterns he was rhyming in.  I'm pretty sure his bars were structured to rhyme with "Lately it seems as if". He went from that, to switching into this rapid / intense flow, to switching back his flow back to rhyme something with "Lately it seems as if". Than, he went back to flowing rapid and intense again, and than went back to rhyme "lately it seems as if" with something else. Some fucking how, Eminem is able to rap as many bars as he wants between the bars that are part of his main rhyme pattern ROYCE... Every bar he spit, his pitch got higher at the end. If he was rapping just a little bit slower I would've thought he was singing. Sometimes I want to ask Royce "do you know what song you're on rn?"}

For example, NYC is not getting split into Brooklyn and Queens and shit. Here it is Los Angeles: K-Dot, Schoolboy Q, Earl Sweatshirt, Snoop Dogg and a Frank Ocean Hook NYC: Nas, Jay-Z, Joey Badass, A$AP Rocky and Alicia Keys Hook Chicago: Kanye, Chance the Rapper, Lupe Fiasco, Chief Keef? with a BJ the chicago kid hook Atlanta: Killa Mike, Childish Gambino?, Andre 3000, T.I and a Bino hook Houston: Riff Raff vs Everybody Drake and Iggy Azalea: White bitches vs Everybody}
{Let me give you some advice. Em is not the greatest of all time in anyone's book. Hell, he isn't even top 5 for me but he is top 10. Recently, he has been wack. It has not been his flow or word play or being sober. It is that he has been rapping the same shit for the past 10 years. It seems like he is trying to remake 8 mile on 3/4's of his albums and on the other quarter he tries to sound hardcore but comes off corny as fuck. His punchlines are way too cheesy and don't fit with the hardcore flow he tries to spit. In my opinion when I look at musical careers, I see Kanye as the better artist. Sure, em has better flow and maybe even better wordplay but Kanye drops projects that all have a different sound and plus he produces. Comparing 2013, Yeezus was a top 15 album of the year and MMLP2 might squeak the top 30 and I did not really enjoy Yeezus. Em needs to drop a final album in the form of an ep that closes his career. It pains me to see him regress like this. Even on this mediocre record, I didn't think he had the best verse. Since everything I heard was about flow, Danny Brown had the best flow in my opinion. I will keep being an Em fan but he very overrated. You guys should listen to more hip hop besides Em and his posse. The world is very big. Listen to the new releases. For the people hatin on "new school" because of 2 chainz, Big Sean, and Lil Wayne, keep in mind that the purpose of those albums are to bang at parties. Many new school artists have the "listening" vibe where you can just sit down and listen to the album like Joey Bada$$, Childish Gambino, and Kendrick Lamar. Then there are the combos that spit "ok" but have amazing flow such as Danny Brown, ASAP Rocky, and Chance the Rapper. The best artists traverse both these realms. Right now, Eminem is not in any of them, I can't play this in the car, I can't play this while working out, I can't sit down with a coffee in a Starbucks and listen, I can't study to this. Em has lost his niche in his purpose as well. You guys should notice that.}

{I like Tupac's style of rapping. He doesn't rap extremely fast and I could understand and appreciate his lyrics more. He also a had nice voice which is a bonus. I really like Eminem, but half of the time I can't understand what he's saying. His lyrics should be more straightforward. It's like reading a book written by an author who thought using a large vocabulary means it's a deep and smart book. Again, this is why I like Tupac's style of rap, his lyrics are simple but still beautifully written. When you're trying to tell a complex story, your writing should be simple so people aren't overwhelmed. I only listened to Tupac after I became a fan of Eminem, but I could clearly see why Tupac is considered better.}

{I don't care for some of these new collaboration tracks. I remember when I was younger and would buy albums, and usually always listen to the tracks that featured other top rappers. But there were usually only a few on each album, so it was like a treat to listen to it. But now, all the videos, all the albums- they're all collaborations. Every possible combination of rapper (and pop star for that matter) is out there- often multiple times. Some of them I like don't get me wrong, but it's just you don't see a lot of albums where a rapper is spitting 80% of it. I still love some of the old collabs; Reservoir Dogs, Young G's (Diddy or not- it's good stuff), World War 3, and my fave Fantastic Four.}

{Eminem may not have known this when he wrote it, but his line about getting along with the voices inside his head is strangely apt. According to psychologist Scott Barry Kaufman, the brains of creative geniuses and people with schizophrenia are similar in surprising ways. They both have an extremely active precuneus, or area that facilitates daydreaming and free association. The only difference is that unlike people with schizophrenia (and Stan), creative geniuses can distinguish between fantasy and reality. I just find this in random websiteÂ }

{Stream InfiniteMC Pred 1 mesecem (urejeno) Â  When Eminem leaves the game, there will be not a single man or woman on earth that wont feel it. If you understood that he IS becoming older and has matured then you would see that he really is "better" as a human. Even if you think that Eminem fell off you have to admit... EVEN DRE (Who is respected as the scout for talent) fell off and produced a few songs that are "good" but they where very mainstream (Kush, sex, money, famous, NONSENSE). If you haven't noticed Eminem (In recent years) hasn't rapped about drugs or killing people or his bad relationships. If you notice closely, this song is (in my point of view) one of Eminem's best because he is admitting that he is getting old and that he has matured ("Id rather make Not Afraid 2 than another motherfucking we made you") and his mentality has changed. In my point of view "Rap God" is a good song that shows his talent as a rapper... Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  |>BUT<|Â  (Guts Over Fear, Legacy, Bad Guy, Evil Twin, Monster, ETC.) talk about how he got to where he is and how he understands his demons. He knows he is getting old and running out of good ideas for lyrics ("But what am I gonna do when the rage is gone? And the lights go out in that trailer park?"). He understands that the public has stopped believing in him because that "Light" and the "spark" of hate that he had with him when he began his career is leaving him ("And the window is closing and there's nowhere else that I can go with flows and I'm frozen cause there's no more emotion for me to pull from just a bunch of playful songs that I made for fun"). His lyrics are softer now because he has understood that life is full of hardships and that we shouldent take it out on others when it could also be his fault. The angry blond will live on in our hearts as long as we keep it there... Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  |>BUT<|Â  We HAVE to realize that slim shady is his DEMON, created by all the hate and mistreatment that he received ("Cause I can't explain to y'all how dang exhausted my legs felt just having to balance my dang self but on eggshells I was made to walk but thank you, ma, 'cause that gave me the strength to cause Shady-mania, so when they empty that stadium at least I made it out of that house and a found a place in this world when the day was done") and that this "Monster" inside him is what made him famous. He WILL NOT go back to that persona and "Monster Feat. Rihanna " explains that. Another example of how Eminem has matured. Listen to the last verse of "Bad Guy" EVERY PART OF THAT VERSE is just incredibly true. Marshall spits his heart out on that verse. It made me cry. Eminem is in pain, he has seen everything that he has done, all of the national hatred that he inspired. All of the bad things rap has done to him. He talks about how he is living a nightmare full of remorse but he wants to keep his fame ("I'm the nightmare you fell asleep in and woke up still in I'm your karma closing in with each stroke of a pen Perfect time to have some remorse to show for your sin No, it's hopeless, I'm the denial that you're hopelessly in When they say all of this is approaching its end But you refuse to believe that it's over, here we go all over again") He also talks about how he has a ("I am your lack of a conscience") lack of a conscience and that he understands that the game controlled his life and now the game is telling him that his round is up but he don't want to go. ("I'm your time that's almost up that you haven't acknowledged Grab for some water but I'm that pill that's too jagged to swallow") There are so many more messages in that last verse of "Bad Guy" that I can explain here. Look for "Eminem - Bad Guy [The Epic "Verse 4"]" and dissect the lyrics and their meaning. That verse is by far the most powerful verse ANY MC has ever spit. Hands down. But most of all he thanks us... He thanks world because he understands that even in tough times, we are his "Soldiers up in his corners" we are (to him) worth more than a Grammy or any award. (Unlike rappers now adays, Nicky Minaj for example wrote "Fuck all you skinny bitches" What the fuck is up with rap now a days?). Eminem wrote this song for world the REAL fans that understand him! ("So this is for every kid who all's they ever did was dreamt of one day just getting accepted, I represent him or her, anyone similar, you are the reason that I made this song and everything you're scared to say don't be afraid to say no more from this day forward, just let them a-holes talk take it with a grain of salt.") When Eminem leaves the game, there will be an emptiness in my heart that will never be filled. Eminem, your TRUE fans are still here and we arn't leaving. I still believe in you. {Its absolutely foolish to say Eminem is bad. Â People don't fully understand the ceiling of talent that he had to reach, and the amount of overall work that needed to be done, to get to the level that he is at now from the time that he was coming up from nothing. Â A lot of these guys who are big now wouldn't of had made it in his young days. Â As soon as hip hop became mainstream and pop, it became more about promotion and less about talent. Â Its now more about having an attractive image that will bring in money for publishers, record labels, and corporations/services that need advertising and hire artists. Â Plus, its all social networking now. Â It isn't about the music, its about sales. Â People will eat up what is thrown in front of them because it is convenient. Â Kids don't need to search for culture when "culture" is fed to them everywhere they look. Â Eminem is a musical legend and always performs better than the majority of other rappers. Â I actually thought Big Sean did better than usual in this song...a little bit of passion and personal substance to move with his "punchline" attraction that everyone seems to be drawn to when it comes to his persona. Â Regardless, kids don't realize that the golden age of hip hop has very much come and gone. Â That's not even up for discussion coming from both a cultural and musical prospective. Â Another thing for kids to note is that production potential has seen major improvements in the passed 15 years. Â Any one can be a producer if they have the will, a little cash, and a computer. Â In the early nineties, when Em was coming up aside other big names like Jay-Z, Nas, and Busta Rhymes (to name a few), a rapper normally had to pay for a studio or get enough attention rapping and battling in public places to have them invite you in to use the tools necessary to produce a track. Â These days someone bad can cost efficiently make something terrible sound perfect, while sitting comfortably on their living room couch. That's an extreme, but I think it establishes my point. Â Its no coincidence that Eminem and those other rappers listed are still relevant in their forties. Â Yeah they have the money to keep putting out music, but Eminem sells more albums than any other rapper in this world because of his skill. Â His character is unique. Â His history is crazy. Â He's been through a wild house of mirrors in his career. Â Yet, at the end of the day, its really just skill. The success is no surprise. Â I don't like all of his verses but none of them are "bad". Â The skill is certainly there. I'd rather have an artist approach skill before content. Â Its the other way around with most rappers and pop artists today. Â Anyway, solid video lol.}

{I ain't from Detroit but I rep it}
{I can understand why some people don't like "Eminem's new flow," but I don't think it's all that bad. It's just different, and it should be. His delivery is way more subdued and (admittedly) monotonous-sounding than all the screaming on Recovery, and of course his voice or style aren't going to sound like what they were on his earlier albums. Times change, as do vocal cords. Personally, I wish he'd raise his voice more often, but the dryer sound he's been using is cool because it's this kind of laid-back, cocky thing that's like, "I'm gonna drop killer verses like it's no big deal because I can." He also uses the same flow pattern (or lack thereof) a lot, but I think it's kind of hard to do anything different when you're trying to pack so many multisyllabic rhymes and punchlines into one verse. I mean, you could probably swap out his verse in this song with one of the ones in "Guts Over Fear" or his verse on the Busta Rhymes song "Calm Down" or something, but I don't think that's a big deal. He's still super-clever and his wordplay is still miles above most other rappers I can think of. So yeah, he's not the same as he used to be, but that's not the same as saying he's not what he once was. P.S. If you're complaining that Eminem's become a "pop star," I assume you say that because he's made some radio-friendly hits and because he's not using as much shock value with his lyrics anymore. Here's my best guess as to why that is the case: he tried to shock and offend people at the beginning of his career to make people listen to him, but he doesn't really need to do that as much anymore because he has already secured a massive fanbase. He has also probably realized that there's value in making some radio-friendly hits that everyone can relate to. I don't think that's a bad thing, because he has lots of good messages that everyone should hear, but if he didn't make more pop-oriented songs to express those messages, not everyone would hear them because a lot of people don't like to hear a bunch of cussing and dark imagery in the music they listen to. In other words, he has grown up a little bit, and if you can't respect him for that, you clearly haven't.}
{I'm not sure if alot of you know this- but this song is very meaninful and holds alot of significance to all the artists featured in it. They all relate to the struggle as one and all have roots starting from Detroit.Â }

{*It's actually pretty lame. Uncreative. Has no meaning. No purpose. Just a bunch of random shots all filmed separately. Remember the days when all the rappers were actually in the same shot? And not all filmed separately all on different days. Remember when music videos had treatments? This video literally has no substance whatsoever. Makes Detroit look like a pile of shit that I'd never want to visit. All dark, dirty and dingy with homeless drug addicts on the street. If you were trying to make Detroit look like a pile of shit you succeeded. It's the only concept Eminem has now. He lives up in a huge house in a private area but comes to the slums to film things in abandoned location then heads back to his life of luxury.* *This video looks like it was shot on a shoes string budget. It's literally, "stand here, in this abandon location, while I point a camera at you." There's nothing to it. I could make this video. This has the same production value as the cypher you just put out. Has the exact same concept as well. "Stand here while I film you and we'll cut it all together. It fucking sucks! Seriously. This video is horrible. Shot with a digital still shot camera that has a video setting. I fucking hate these people making videos with these commercially sold cameras that anyone and their mother can buy. Remember the cameras they use to shoot videos with? You the average person couldn't afford it, and they didn't sell them in Buy Best. It's what separated the professorial film makers from the amateur. Now that line is blurred and everything looks amateur because it's just a bunch of amateurs who think they're professional. Everyone and their mother can buy a camera and edit a video on a computer. Now even big names in the business hire these amateurs directors who edit their videos on a home computer. What the fuck is that? Hype Williams never shot a video on a fuckin digital camera and then edited it on a fuckin laptop.* *Music videos use to be a big industry with big companies and creative concepts and creative directors. Now it's reduced to nothing but student films. Now all you have to do to became a director is go to Best Buy and get a camera and a laptop, and now you're a music video director. It's one thing when amateur rappers do it, you expect their video to be amateur, but when one of the biggest names in rap starts doing it, that's when you know shit is finally over!*}
